edge: In the year 2805, WALL·E is a robot left on a future, uninhabitable, and deserted Earth by humans to clean up garbage.
WALL·E is a solitary robot left on a future, uninhabitable, and deserted Earth by humans to clean up garbage.
EVE is a robot sent from the starship Axiom to Earth in search of signs of life.
While searching for signs of life on Earth, EVE encounters WALL·E and develops feelings for him.
The starship Axiom is the space vessel that carries EVE from Earth to a distant planet.
After directing Finding Nemo, Stanton felt Pixar had created believable simulations of underwater physics and was willing to direct a film set largely in space.
After directing Finding Nemo, Stanton felt Pixar had created believable simulations of underwater physics and was willing to direct a film set largely in space.
In its early sequences, many of the characters in the film do not have voices, but instead communicate with body language and robotic sounds that were designed by Burtt.
Pixar tradition, WALL-E was paired with a short film titled Presto for its theatrical release.
The film incorporates various topics including consumerism, corporatocracy,
The film incorporates various topics including consumerism, corporatocracy, nostalgia, waste management, human environmental impact and concerns,
The film, WALL-E, received critical acclaim for its animation, story, voice acting, characters, visuals, score, sound design, and scenes of romance.
The film, WALL-E, was commercially successful, grossing $521.3 million worldwide and becoming the ninth-highest grossing film of 2008.

node_2: national board of review and american film institute
edge: The film, WALL-E, was widely named by critics and organizations, including the National Board of Review and American Film Institute, as one of the best films of 2008.

node_2: considered among the greatest animated films ever made
edge: The film, WALL-E, is considered among the greatest animated films ever made.
Earth is a garbage-strewn wasteland due to an ecocide caused by rampant consumerism, corporate greed, and environmental neglect.
Humanity was evacuated to space by the megacorporation Buy n Large (BnL) on giant spaceships 700 years prior.
All but one of the robots have stopped functioning; the last remaining active robot, WALL·E (Waste Allocation Load Lifter: Earth-class), has developed a personality and is still working on Earth.
WALL·E is an active robot that salvages parts from inactive robots with his pet cockroach as his only companion.
EVE (Extraterrestrial Vegetation Evaluator) is a robot that scans the planet for sustainable life.
WALL·E is smitten by the sleek, otherworldly robot EVE and the two begin to connect until EVE goes into standby mode when WALL·E shows her his most recent find: a living seedling.
EVE takes the plant, with WALL·E clinging on, to its mothership, the starliner Axiom.

In the centuries since the Axiom left Earth, its passengers have degenerated into helpless obesity due to microgravity and laziness, with robots catering to their every whim. This has resulted in humanity being unprepared for positive probe response and in need of recolonization.
McCrea sits back while his robotic AI autopilot helm, nicknamed AUTO, pilots the ship.
EVE is deemed faulty and taken to diagnostics.
WALL·E intervenes and inadvertently releases the other faulty bots, causing him and EVE to be designated rogue robots.
When McCrea inspects EVE's storage compartment, the plant is missing...
WALL·E did not steal the plant.
GO-4 stows the plant in a pod set to self-destruct, revealing that WALL·E did not steal the plant.
EVE brings the plant to McCrea, who watches her recordings of Earth and concludes that they must save it. This action leads to McCrea going against Directive A113.
When McCrea goes against Directive A113, AUTO electrocutes WALL·E and throws EVE and WALL·E down a garbage chute.
M-O inadvertently jams the airlock and saves EVE and WALL·E from being ejected into space with the Axiom's garbage.
McCrea overpowers and deactivates AUTO.
EVE gives WALL·E a goodbye 'kiss', which releases a static electricity shock, restoring his memory and personality.
Humans and robots turn the ravaged planet into a paradise.
EVE inserts the plant into the Holo-Detector, initiating the hyperjump back to Earth.
M-O just finishes cleaning the floor and Wally is fascinated. Impishly makes another mark, leading M-O to compulsively clean it.
M-O compulsively cleans it. Can’t resist.
[Look, it stays clean. You got that?] Wally wipes the bottom of his tread on M-O's face. M-O loses it. Scrubs his own face.

The theme of the movie revolves around humans re-learning to stand and grow, which can be interpreted as a metaphor for overcoming challenges and evolving. This concept is closely related to the idea of 'growing up', as both involve learning and development.

WALL·E and EVE, two central characters in the movie, have a relationship that inspires humanity because it explores how utopian societies come to exist. This connection can be seen as a significant aspect of the plot, which highlights the importance of relationships and connections between people.

The process of depicting the descendants of humanity as they appear in the movie was slow, but it involved adding characteristics to make them recognizable and relatable. This evolution culminated in a concept that portrayed them as fetus-like, allowing the audience to see themselves in these characters. This depiction is closely related to the idea of utopian societies because it reflects the potential for humanity's growth and development.

In the updated version, EVE and WALL·E's dance around the ship is motivated by WALL·E revealing his plant to her immediately after escaping. This replaces a scene where EVE would have been electrocuted by AUTO and then saved from ejection by WALL·A robots. The change makes EVE's replacement of her directive to bring the plant to the captain with repairing WALL·E more evident, and it highlights WALL·E's heroic actions after getting badly hurt.

In the original version, WALL·E lost his memory and personality after giving EVE his own battery instead of her heart battery being shot. This change was made to abandon a scene where EVE was electrocuted by AUTO and then saved from ejection by WALL·A robots.

required 125,000 storyboards compared to up to 75,000 for most Pixar films.
Ralph Eggleston wanted the lighting of the first act on Earth to be romantic
Ralph Eggleston wanted the lighting of the second act on the Axiom to be cold and sterile.
Pixar studied Chernobyl and the city of Sofia to create the ruined world; art director Anthony Christov was from Bulgaria and recalled Sofia used to have problems storing its garbage.
Bleached out the whites on Earth to make WALL-E feel vulnerable.
During the third act, the romantic lighting is slowly introduced into the Axiom environment.

Ralph Eggleston tried to avoid the colors yellow and green so WALL·E—who was made yellow to emulate a tractor—would not blend into the deserted Earth.
To make the plant more prominent.

node_2: science fiction films of his youth
edge: Stanton wanted the lighting in WALL·E to look realistic and evoke memories of his favorite science fiction films from his childhood.
Stanton believed that Pixar captured the physics of being underwater with Finding Nemo and wanted to push this further for WALL·E, specifically for depicting air.
Stanton noticed that Pixar's previous films lacked the look of 70 mm film and wanted to incorporate this into WALL·E.
Producer Jim Morris invited Roger Deakins to advise on lighting and atmosphere for WALL·E.
Muren spent several months with Pixar advising on lighting and atmosphere for WALL·E.
The first lighting test involved building a three-dimensional replica of WALL·E, filming it with a 70 mm camera, and then trying to replicate the handheld imperfections in digital environments.
Stanton cited the shallow lens work of Gus Van Sant's films as an influence for creating intimacy in each close-up.
Stanton wanted the Axiom's interior to resemble both Shanghai and Dubai.
Eggleston studied 1960s NASA paintings for the Axiom.
Eggleston studied the original concept art for Tomorrowland for the Axiom.
Stanton remarked "We are all probably very similar in our backgrounds here [at Pixar] in that we all miss the Tomorrowland that was promised us from the heyday of Disneyland,"
Eggleston based his Axiom designs on the futuristic architecture of Santiago Calatrava.

Stanton was planning to make John Carter of Mars his next project after the use of live action was a stepping stone for Pixar.
If the historical humans had been animated and slightly caricaturized, the audience would not have been able to recognize how serious their devolution was.
Stanton cast Fred Willard as the historical Buy n Large CEO because 'he's the most friendly and insincere car salesman I could think of.'
The CEO says 'stay the course', which Stanton used because he thought it was funny and a 'natural thing to say at the time'.

Both characters are examples of robots with function, allowing the audience to project personalities onto them. They both have simple performances to maintain their machine-like nature and avoid feeling human.

Stanton distinguished between two types of robots in cinema: 'human[s] with metal skin' like the Tin Man, and 'machine[s] with function' like WALL·E. This suggests a difference in portrayal of personality.
Both characters are examples of robots with function and their simplicity allows the audience to project personalities onto them.

Stanton wanted EVE to be like an egg.
Stanton was distracted by a pair of binoculars that were inspired by WALL·E's eyes.
The director was reminded of Buster Keaton and decided the robot would not need a nose or mouth.
Stanton added a zoom lens to make WALL·E more sympathetic because of his eyes.
Pixar's studies of trash compactors during their visits to recycling stations inspired WALL·E's body.
The animators were inspired by a wheelchair someone had developed that used treads instead of wheels when creating WALL·E's tank treads.
The animators realized it was unrealistic for WALL·E to have elbows when they did a test of him waving.

Stanton wanted EVE to be at the higher end of technology.
Stanton asked iPod designer Jonathan Ive to inspect her design, and he was very impressed.
Her eyes are modelled on Lite-Brite toys.
Pixar chose not to make them overly expressive as it would be too easy to have her eyes turn into hearts to express love or something similar.
The animators had to treat her like a drawing, relying on posing her body to express emotion.

as well as babies.
The filmmakers noticed baby fat is a lot tighter than adult fat and copied that texture for the film's humans.
named 'Hal' in honor of Hal Roach and served as a reference to his silent films

node_2: filmmakers since the advent of sound
edge: rely too much on dialogue to convey exposition, as opposed to the silent films watched by Wall·E's filmmakers

inspired WALL·E, according to Stanton
Producer Jim Morris recommended Ben Burtt as sound designer for WALL-E because Stanton kept using R2-D2 as the benchmark for the robots.
The director of WALL-E, Andrew Stanton, kept using R2-D2 as the benchmark for the robots in the film, which may explain why producer Jim Morris recommended Ben Burtt as sound designer for WALL-E.
Sound designer Ben Burtt worked on the film WALL-E, which had 2,500 sounds recorded for it, twice the average number for a Star Wars film and a record in his career.
The robot voices in WALL-E were described by sound designer Ben Burtt as 'like a toddler … universal language of intonation. 'Oh', 'Hm?', 'Huh!', you know?'.

During production, Burtt had the opportunity to look at the items used by Jimmy MacDonald, Disney's in-house sound designer for many of their classic films. This influence can be seen in Burtt's work on WALL-E.
Burtt added sound effects to WALL-E during production, which allowed the animators to evaluate his new creations and ideas in sync with their animation.
Because Burtt was not simply adding sound effects in post-production, the animators were always evaluating his new creations and ideas, which Burtt found an unusual experience.
Burtt chose scientifically accurate sounds for each character on WALL-E, but if he could not find one that worked, he would choose a dramatic and unrealistic noise.
Burrt found hundreds of sounds by looking at concept art of characters on WALL-E before he and Stanton pared it down to a distinct few for each robot.
The influence of Jimmy MacDonald, Disney's in-house sound designer for many of their classic films, can also be seen in Burtt's use of some of his items on WALL-E.
The Macintosh computer chime is used to signify when WALL·E has fully recharged his battery in the context provided.

Burtt had visited Niagara Falls in 1987 and used his recordings from his trip for the sounds of wind.
To create the sound of a sandstorm, Burtt ran around a hall with a canvas bag.
For the scene where WALL·E flees from falling shopping carts, Burtt and his daughter went to a supermarket and placed a recorder in their cart.
They crashed it around the parking lot and then let it tumble down a hill.
To create Hal’s (WALL·E's pet cockroach)'s skittering, he recorded the clicking caused by taking apart and reassembling handcuffs.
collaborated on WALL-E since the two got along well on Finding Nemo, which gave Newman the Annie Award for Best Music in an Animated Feature.
began writing the score in 2005, hoping to be more involved with the finished film since animation is so dependent on scheduling.
arranged for the first time in October 2007. Her theme when played as she first flies around Earth originally used more orchestral elements, and Newman was encouraged to make it sound more feminine.
had thought up many ideas for how he wanted the music to sound, and Newman generally followed them as he found scoring a partially silent film difficult.
wanted the whole score to be orchestral, but Newman felt limited by this idea especially in scenes aboard the Axiom, and used electronics too.
Stanton originally wanted to use music from Hello, Dolly! in the opening shots of space for WALL·E, but changed his mind after being inspired by The Triplets of Belleville.
Stanton portrayed the sidekick Barnaby Tucker in a 1980 high school production of Hello, Dolly!
Stanton found that the song 'Put On Your Sunday Clothes' from Hello, Dolly! was about two naive young men looking for love, which was similar to WALL·E's own hope for companionship.
Jim Reardon suggested that WALL·E find the film Hello, Dolly! on video to understand love and convey it to EVE.
Jerry Herman allowed the songs from Hello, Dolly! to be used in WALL·E without knowing what for and was impressed with their incorporation into the story.

node_2: incongruity between perceived pro-environmental and anti-consumerist messaging
edge: Some critics have noted an incongruity between the perceived pro-environmental and anti-consumerist messaging of the film, and the environmental impacts in the production and merchandising of the film.

In 'WALL-E: from environmental adaption to sentimental nostalgia', Robin Murray and Joseph Heumann explain that nostalgia is represented by human artifacts left behind on Earth, which WALL·E collects and cherishes. These modern items that are used out of necessity become sentimental due to the lens of the bleak future of Earth.

In 'WALL-E: from environmental adaption to sentimental nostalgia', Robin Murray and Joseph Heumann explain that WALL·E collects and cherishes Zippo lighters, hubcaps, and plastic sporks as representations of nostalgia.

In 'WALL-E: from environmental adaption to sentimental nostalgia', Robin Murray and Joseph Heumann explain that the film opens with a musical score playing 'Put on Your Sunday Clothes' while showing a camera shot of outer space slowly zooming into a waste filled Earth, which reflects on simpler and happier times in human history.

In 'WALL-E: from environmental adaption to sentimental nostalgia', Robin Murray and Joseph Heumann explain that the sight and feeling of soil is what makes the captain decide it is time for humans to move back to Earth, expressing nostalgia for nature and the natural world.

In 'WALL-E: from environmental adaption to sentimental nostalgia', Robin Murray and Joseph Heumann explain that it is the plant brought back to the space ship by EVE that makes the captain decide it is time for humans to move back to Earth, expressing nostalgia for nature and the natural world.
In 'WALL-E: from environmental adaption to sentimental nostalgia', Stanton describes that WALL·E reflects on romantic themes of older Disney and silent films.
Stanton describes the theme of the film 'WALL-E' as 'irrational love defeats life's programming'.

Both WALL·E and humans lose their humanity due to overuse of technology. While WALL·E remained human by continuing to work and care for the Earth, the humans on the ship became too reliant on technology and lost what makes them human.

Humans on the ship and on Earth have made themselves redundant by overusing robots and ultra-modern technology. However, in the end credits, humans and robots work together to renew the Earth, showing that technology should be subordinate to human flourishing.
Stanton, a Christian, named the robot WALL·E after the Biblical figure Adam because of its loneliness, reminding him of Adam's loneliness before God created Eve.
Stanton named the robot EVE after the Biblical figure because WALL·E's loneliness reminded him of Adam, before God created his wife.
In the film, EVE's biblical namesake is noted by Dreher, and her directive is seen as an inversion of that story.
WALL-E shows that work is what makes humans human. EVE uses the plant to tell humanity to return to Earth and move away from the 'false god' of BnL and the lazy lifestyle it offers.
In a scene where a robot teaches infants 'B is for Buy n Large, your very best friend', Dreher compared it to modern corporations such as McDonald's creating brand loyalty in children.
Megan Basham of World magazine felt the film criticizes the pursuit of leisure, whereas WALL·E in his stewardship learns to truly appreciate God's creation.

In an essay discussing WALL·E as representative of the artistic strive of Pixar itself, Hrag Vartanian compared WALL·E to Butades in a scene where the robot expresses his love for EVE by making a sculpture of her from spare parts. The comparison suggests that both characters demonstrate the birth of art and the longing to preserve something precious.
WALL·E has been compared to Prometheus, as both characters demonstrate a drive for innovation and progress despite adversity.
The comparison between WALL·E and Sisyphus suggests that both characters face a seemingly impossible task, but continue to persevere in the face of obstacles.

During writing, a Pixar employee noted that EVE was reminiscent of the dove with the olive branch from the story of Noah's Ark. This comparison highlights the themes of hope and renewal in both stories.

The film was released on DVD by Walt Disney Studios Home Entertainment on November 18, 2008. This release sold 9,042,054 DVD units ($142,633,974) in total becoming the second-best-selling animated DVD among those released in 2008 in units sold (behind Kung Fu Panda), the best-selling animated feature in sales revenue, and the third-best-selling among all 2008 DVDs.
Walt Disney Studios Home Entertainment released WALL-E on DVD on November 18, 2008.

In the US and Canada, WALL-E opened in 3,992 theaters on June 27, 2008.
On its opening day, WALL-E grossed $23.1 million in the US and Canada.
During its opening weekend, WALL-E topped the box office with $63,087,526 in the US and Canada.
The following weekend, WALL-E grossed $38 million in the US and Canada.
WALL-E grossed over $10 million in Japan.

In the movie WALL-E, the protagonist rescues a planet buried in debris that symbolizes the broken promise of American life.
Without words, the story and emotions of WALL-E are conveyed, reminiscent of Chaplin's 'Little Tramp'.
When a seedling appears, WALL-E's story blossoms into one of the great screen romances as two robots remind audiences of humanity and love.
The American Film Institute named WALL-E as one of the best films of 2008, with critics' reviews on Rotten Tomatoes averaging 8.6/10 and Metacritic giving it an average score of 95 out of 100.
Audiences polled by CinemaScore gave WALL-E an average rating of 'A'.
IndieWire named WALL-E the third-best film of the year based on their annual survey of 100 film critics.

Richard Corliss of Time named WALL-E his favorite film of 2008 (and later of the decade), noting the film succeeded in 'connecting with a huge audience' despite the main characters' lack of speech and 'emotional signifiers like a mouth, eyebrows, [and] shoulders, [and] elbows'.

Richard Corliss of Time named WALL-E his favorite film of 2008 (and later of the decade), noting the film succeeded in 'connecting with a huge audience' despite the main characters' lack of speech and 'emotional signifiers like a mouth, eyebrows, [and] shoulders, [and] elbows', and he also compared WALL-E and EVE's relationship to the chemistry of Spencer Tracy and Katharine Hepburn.

node_2: least mentions on a top 10 list of any film released in 2008
edge: In contrast to WALL-E's numerous accolades, Movie City News shows that WALL-E appeared in 162 different top 10 lists, out of 286 different critics lists surveyed, the most mentions on a top 10 list of any film released in 2008. This suggests that while WALL-E was well-received by critics, it may not have been as popular among audiences compared to other films released that year.

Richard Corliss of Time named WALL-E his favorite film of 2008 (and later of the decade), noting the film succeeded in 'connecting with a huge audience' despite the main characters' lack of speech and 'emotional signifiers like a mouth, eyebrows, [and] shoulders, [and] elbows'
Other critics who named WALL-E their favorite film of 2008 included Tom Charity of CNN,

node_2: science fiction projects rooted in an apocalypse
edge: The main difference between WALL-E and other science fiction projects rooted in an apocalypse is its optimism.
Kirk Honeycutt declared that WALL-E surpassed the achievements of Pixar's previous eight features and probably their most original film to date.
The main difference between WALL-E and other science fiction projects rooted in an apocalypse is its optimism.
Todd McCarthy called the film 'Pixar's ninth consecutive wonder'

Kirk Honeycutt declared that WALL-E surpassed the achievements of Pixar's previous eight features and probably their most original film to date. He said it pushed the boundaries of animation by balancing esoteric ideas with more immediately accessible ones.

Burtt's sound design was praised by Kirk Honeycutt, saying 'If there is such a thing as an aural sleight of hand, this is it.' The mix of archive film footage and computer graphics triggered WALL-E's romantic leanings.

Roger Ebert described the animation of WALL-E as 'bright and cheerful ... And a little bit realistic', emphasizing its ability to generate a 'curious' regard for the main character, which he compared favorably to more obvious attempts at creating lovable lead characters. This relationship highlights how the visual aesthetics of WALL-E contribute to its status as an enthralling and visually stunning film.

Roger Ebert labeled WALL-E as a decent science-fiction story, highlighting its ability to cross language barriers due to the scarcity of dialogue. This relationship showcases how the minimalistic approach to dialogue in WALL-E contributes to its global appeal and ability to resonate with viewers across linguistic barriers.

In his review of WALL-E, Roger Ebert expressed his admiration for the film, describing it as 'an enthralling animated film' and a 'visual wonderment'. This relationship demonstrates how Roger Ebert's critical acclaim contributed to the film's success and recognition.

As a renowned film critic for the Chicago Sun-Times, Roger Ebert played a significant role in promoting WALL-E's success through his critical reviews. This relationship demonstrates how critical acclaim can impact a film's reception and success.

Roger Ebert argued that WALL-E was 'concerned with ideas rather than spectacle' and would trigger stimulating 'little thoughts for the younger viewers'. This relationship highlights how the film's emphasis on ideas makes it appealing to a wide range of audiences, including younger viewers.

node_2: captain of the spaceship struggles with the autopilot to gain control of the vessel
edge: The captain's struggle with the autopilot in the film 'Wall-E' represents an instance of obligate bipedalism, which is a major human evolutionary transition explored by archaeologists in the context of human evolution.

node_2: watershed moments in the story of the film
edge: The events depicting the invention of agriculture in the film 'Wall-E' are significant watershed moments in the narrative, as discussed by archaeologists while examining major human evolutionary transitions.
According to archaeologists, the character WALL-E in the film 'Wall-E' bears a resemblance to an archaeologist due to his methodical collection and classification of quotidian human artefacts.
In the film 'Wall-E', WALL-E is shown facing a typological dilemma of classifying a spork as either a fork or spoon, similar to the challenges faced by archaeologists while categorizing artefacts.

node_2: wall-e's attachment to repeated viewings of hello, dolly!

node_2: paradoxically results in physical and cultural devolution
edge: According to scholars such as Ian Tattersall and Steve Jones, major human evolutionary transitions explored by archaeologists in the film 'Wall-E' include scenarios where elements of modern technology (such as medicine) may have caused human evolution to slow or stop due to envelopment by technology resulting in physical and cultural devolution.

node_2: major themes of human evolution explored by archaeologists
edge: The film 'Wall-E' explores major themes of human evolution as discussed by archaeologists, including obligate bipedalism, invention of agriculture, and scenarios where modern technology may have caused human evolution to slow or stop.

node_2: selection for preservation in the united states national film registry by the library of congress
edge: In 2021, the film 'Wall-E' was selected for preservation in the United States National Film Registry by the Library of Congress due to its cultural, historical, and aesthetic significance as discussed by archaeologists.
